 Abs tract This paper analyzes the 1978-81 foreign exchange crisis and 1982-90 medium- term prospects for Turkey using a computable general equilibrium (CGE) model of the Turkish economy. Through a series of historical simulations, the model attempts to capture the basic features of the 1978-81 foreign exchange disequilibrium in Turkey and evaluate their role in the crisis. The model is then used to undertake a series of forward runs for the 1982-90 period which reflect alternative scenarios as to the success and viability of the ongoing shift in Turkish development policy from inward-looking import substitution to outward-focused export expansion.

 1. Introduction By 1978, Turkey was in the midst of the most serious foreign exchange and economic crisis it had experienced in three decades. Although the Turkish economy appeared to weather the first oil price increase and related international disruptions of the early 1970s with relative ease, the high (over 7 percent) GDP growth rate sustained over the 1973-77 period was largely attributable to increased foreign borrowing and favorable trends in workers' remittances. With the onset of the second oil price increase in 1978 and 1979, the persistence of stagflation in Turkey's major trading partners, and the growing strains in the Turkish economy (characterized by exchange rate overvaluation and accelerating domestic inflation), the growth momentum of the mid-1970s collapsed and Turkey entered a period of negative GDP growth and severe foreign exchange rationing. This stagnation continued until 1981 when the remarkable 62 percent growth of exports (in dollars) alleviated the foreign exchange shortage and permitted GDP growth of around 4 percent, which has continued into 1982. While the export-led economic recovery is attributable in part to the depressed level of domestic demand, another major factor is the government's reorientation towards an outward-oriented development strategy, as embodied in the exchange rate reforms, import liberalization and export subsidy programs implemented since early 1980. This paper presents an analysis of the 1978-80 crisis period in Turkey and an exploration of the feasibility and sustainability of the ongoing export-led recovery. We make use of the results derived from the latest variant of computable general equilibrium (CGE) models that have increasingly been applied to issues of policy choice and development strategy in developing countries, including earlier applications to Turkey (see Dervis and Robinson (1978) and (1982)) and Yugoslavia.
 -2- Section 2 of the paper provides a brief introduction to the features of the CGE model, which is supplemented by a more detailed description and algebraic presentation in Appendix I. The current version of the CGE model incorporates a number of features that facilitate an historical examination of the turbulent foreign exchange disequilibria of the 1978-80 period. Turkish authorities responded to the severe foreign exchange shortage by rationing imports, resorting to a varying mix of quantitative controls and premia schemes to restrict imports. The CGE model simulates the simultaneous operation of both types of schemes, as well as producing measures of the total "rents" generated by such rationing mechanisms and their impact on productivity and capacity utilization. Section 3 presents an analysis of the 1978-81 historical period. The historical antecedents to the recent crisis are described and the macroeconomic characteristics of Turkey are contrasted with those of a sample of twelve other middle-income countries (MICs). Turkey is found to differ substantially from the sample average with regards both to the low importance of exports and imports in GDP (i.e. the degree of "openness") and to the sizeable share of agriculture in both GDP and employment. The economic developments of the 1978-81 period are described in some detail, and the features of the shift in development strategy that was first articulated in the 1980 trade reforms are outlined. Comparison of the sources of output growth for 1978-81 with earlier periods reveals strong discontinuities in the import policies adopted by the government, with periods of import liberalization alternating with foreign exchange shortage and import restriction. The quantitative analysis is based on the fitting of the CGE model to the 1978-81 period (or "validation"), and the subsequent simulation of a number of counterfactual "alternative" scenarios designed to disentangle

Model simulations reveal that the "cost" to the economy of delay in the adoption of the new outward-looking strategy was substantial, and that the role of the oil price increase, while significant, was less important than changes in the real exchange rate due to high domestic inflation in bringing about the foreign exchange crisis. Turning from historical analysis to medium-term projections, Section 4 of the paper presents a number of alternative scenarios for growth in the Turkish economy during the 1982-90 period. Based on the phenomenal growth of exports during 1981 and 1982, and the high net inflow of foreign capital, Turkey enters 1983 in a better situation than at any time since the early 1970s. Using the CGE model,. this section develops a Forward Base Run that assumes that the government adopts trade and domestic management policies that will permit the ongoing shift to export-led growth to be successful, with exports reaching nearly 20 percent of GDP by 1990, and that facilitate the rapid growth of private investment, resulting not only in a drastic reduction in the role of public investment but an overall increase in the share of investment in GDP as well. This Base Run is then contrasted with a number of alternative forward scenarios, with special focus placed on the role of export performance, productivity growth, exchange rate policy, and private investment as critical determinants of economic performance in the coming decade. The macroeconomic implications of the various scenarios are considered, as well as their impact on sectoral structure. Finally, the feasibility of the Turkish export orientation is considered by using the "demand sources of growth" methodology to contrast the Turkish projections with the experience of other countries pursuing export-led strategies. Appendix I contains a detailed description and' algebraic summary of the model, while Appendix II outlines the data sources used for the study.

An Overview of the CGE Model I/ The current CGE model of Turkey is the latest in a long tradition of non-linear, computable general equilibrium models that stem from the early work of Johansen (1960). In recent years, this class of models has been used as instruments of planning and policy analysis in conjunction with World Bank research and evaluation of the performance and prospects of developing nations, including Bank Missions to Turkey in 1979 and 1982 and the Yugoslavia Plan Review Mission in 1981-2/ The chief characteristic of a CGE model is that it simulates the working of a market system in which prices vary in various markets (for factors, products, and foreign exchange) in response to changes in supply and demand conditions. In contrast to the simpler, linear input-output models that assume no change in relative prices, a CGE model permits the simulation of the results of policy packages which operate through the price mechanism, such as exchange rates, tariffs and export subsidies. Economic performance is seen as the outcome of decentralized optimizing decisions made by producers and consumers in response to market conditions, which in turn are influenced by government policies, international economic conditions, and other exogenous forces. It is important to stress that a CGE model, like the simpler input- output model, is primarily a simulation model to be used for planning purposes, not a forecasting model. It is intended to be applied to periods long enough that market mechanisms can be expected to respond to changes in 1/ A more complete presentation of the model is contained in Appendix I. 2/ See, for example, World Bank (1980a).
 -5- market conditions. Within each period, the model reaches, a static equilibrium solution in which all markets are modeled as clearing subject to specified behavioral rules and parameter values. This approach is in stark contrast to standard macroeconomic forecasting models, which derive their results from complex specifications as to the speed at which markets respond to changing economic conditions, and the different structure of these adjustment lags in various sectors of the economy. The CGE model is thus not intended for macroeconomic forecasting, but instead concentrates on the determination of relative prices among sectors and on the structure of real variables in the economy. The model is Walrasian and hence only determines relative prices. The selection of a numeraire or price normalization rule exogenously fixes the absolute price level, so that a solution to the model yields sectoral prices relative to the specified aggregate price level. The domestic rate of inflation is also specified exogenously, and the real focus of the model is further reflected in the complete absence of financial markets or monetary variables. Another consequence of the real focus of the model relates to the exchange rate. Just as the prices of outputs in all sectors are relative prices, so too is the exchange rate treated as a relative price within the model. What matters to the model is not the nominal level of the exchange rate over time, but rather whether the exchange rate movements are greater or less than the differential between domestic and world inflation. If the change in the nominal exchange rate from period to period just offsets differential world and domestic inflation rates, this corresponds to a constant real (or price level deflated) exchange rate. Only if the change in the exchange rate exceeds (falls short of) this differential will there be a depreciation (appreciation) in the real exchange rate. If one were to raise
 -6- the estimate of domestic inflation for a certain period, and raise the nominal exchange rate by the same proportion, this would have no impact on any of the real variables in the model. It is worth emphasizing at this point that the idea of markets responding to changing economic conditions does not imply that markets are "perfect" in the neoclassical sense. Instead, the model explicitly takes account of rigidities and distortions in the economy, and attempts to model them formally. For example, capital already in place in each sector is fixed, with the capital stock modified only through the allocation of new investment, and sectoral wages for each type of labor are required to conform to an exogenously specified pattern embodying wage "distortions" existing in Turkish labor markets. When the model is operated intertemporally, it is necessary to specify how the exogenous variables change over time. When the model is used to examine future economic prospects, this implies forecasting the movement of these exogenous variables. In some cases (e.g. employment growth), these forecasts can be derived from extrapolation of historical trends; in other cases, (foreign capital inflows, investment allocation and levels), greater judgement is required since the magnitudes are presumably quite dependent on the performance of the economy itself, which in turn is responsive to the full range of government policy instruments (the exchange rate, tariffs and subsidies, tax policy). This last point deserves further emphasis. All projections generated by the model are conditional on the specific policy packages simulated and the projected levels of exogenous variables. Government policy plays a dominant role in the results, so that the choice among alternative scenarios is contingent on the government undertaking all of the policies simulated in the model.

Turkish Economic Performance, 1973-77: A Perspective The 1973-77 period in Turkey can be aptly characterized by the dramatic swing that occurred from a positive to a negative foreign exchange balance. Although foreign exchange crises had been associated with economic cycles in the past, the crisis which culminated in 1977 was much more serious than the previous ones, not only because of its magnitude, but also because of the severe domestic and foreign economic disruptions that accompanied it. Real GDP increased at an annual rate of 7.3 percent between 1970 and 1977 2. This growth rate compares favorably with 6.0. percent growth rate during the 1960s. Moreover, a high GDP growth rate of 7.2 percent was maintained during the Third Plan Period (1973-77), despite the first oil shock and its aftermath.21 Although this high growth rate of real GDP was partly attributable to government policies that insulated the Turkish economy and postponed adjustment to changing world conditions, dramatic increases in production in the industrial (mining, manufacturing and electricity, gas, water) and services sectors did occur. Recent Economic Events and Policy Reforms, 1978-81 In response to the growing foreign exchange crisis in 1977, the new government under Prime Minister Ecevit undertook a stabilization program beginning early in 1978, which met with only mixed success. While the current account deficit improved markedly from $3.6 billion in 1977 to $1.7 billion in 1978, domestic inflation worsened as prices rose more than 50 percent. A new stabilization program was announced in March 1979 and amplified in the following months, culminating in a standby arrangement with the IMF in July 1979. Despite these stringent measures, inflation accelerated to 64 percent in 1979. The balance of payments situation remained stable, with a $1.8 billion deficit on the current account. On the trade side, as Figure 3.3 and Table 3.3 indicate, total exports stagnated in 1979, with a slight decrease occurring in merchandise exports. At the same time, the inflow of external capital, especially commercial borrowing, dried up. As a result, imports had to be reduced substantially. In dollar terms, imports of goods fell by 21 percent in 1978 and rose by only 10 percent in 1979 compared to 1977 levels. The volume of oil imports declined to 11.7 million tons in 1979 from 14.3 million tons in 1978. The shift toward a more outward- oriented development strategy has already begun to produce tangible results, as evident in the tremendous upsurge in exports in 1981-82 and the alleviation of the foreign exchange shortage and import rationing distortions of the 1978-80 period. However, as the other scenarios described in this section suggest, this relatively optimistic Base Run is dependent on an interrelated combination of government policies and specific forecasts of world conditions.  Appendix I: The Turkey CGE Model The model currently being used is a descendant of the TGT (Turkey Growth and Trade) model developed by Dervis and Robinson for the Bank Mission to Turkey of April, 1979. The report of that mission has been published and a thorough exposition of that earlier model is available.1/ This appendix describes the features of the new model, emphasizing major changes and enhancements that have been implemented since the earlier work. A parallel model with many similar features has also been developed for Yugoslavia by Robinson and Tyson. That model has been used to analyze the impact of adjustment policies in Yugoslavia. A. The CGE Model Formulation The overall CGE model is divided into a static, annual general equilibrium model and a separate between-period model which provides the necessary intertemporal linkages. The static model is described in some detail in this section, after which the structure of the intertemporal model is presented. A.1 Product Markets and Factor Supplies There are 13 sectors or product markets in the Turkey CGE model. The model assumes that each sector produces a single good, and for each such good formulates conditions of supply and demand. Since most of these markets are for tradeable goods - that is goods for which there are exports and/or imports in the input-output and national accounts - it is useful to begin the discussion with the model's specification of export and import behavior. The model assumes that domestically produced goods and imports are imperfect 1/ See World Bank (1980a) and Dervis and Robinson (1978).
 - A-2 - substitutes. For each of these sectors, the model defines a "composite" good which is an aggregation of the domestic good and the imported substitute. This trade aggregation function is represented by a CES specification, in which the elasticity of substitution between the domestic good and imported substitute plays an important role. Elasticities of substitution vary across sectors, with smaller elasticities reflecting greater differences between the domestic and imported good, and hence greater difficulty in substituting one for the other in response to changes in their relative prices. For Turkey, the elasticity used in agriculture is quite high, those for the consumer goods sectors more moderate (e.g. food processing, textiles and light intermediates), and those for capital goods and petroleum quite low, reflecting the difficulty of substituting limited domestic substitutes for these imported commodities. 1/ Assuming that users of a good seek to minimize the cost of acquiring it, this formulation yields the result that the desired ratio of the imported substitute to the domestically produced good is a function of the ratio of their prices. Following the small-country assumption, the world price of the imported substitute is assumed fixed by world market conditions over which Turkey has no influence, and the supply of imports to Turkey is infinitely elastic at that price. The domestic price of the import substitute is determined by the world price, the tariff rate, the premium rate on imports and the exchange rate 2/ Two different portrayals of the operation of export markets are currently possible. Consistent with this specification, the model will assume that Turkish exports are a function of domestic supply conditions rather than foreign demand conditions. This is often modelled by setting sectoral export targets exogenously. Alternatively, since frequently the domestic currency price of an export may not equal its price on the domestic market, one can specify that exporters have an upward- sloping supply curve for exports, where the relevant price is the ratio of the domestic currency price of exports to the domestic price. In other runs, the model requires that export markets clear through equilibrating supply and demand functions, in which case export supply in each sector depends on the ratio of the export price to the domestic price, and the world demand for Turkish exports is given by a downward sloping demand curve. Finally, in the model, the absolute price level is set exogenously and is given by a weighted index of sectoral prices. Because the CGE model focuses on the determination of relative prices among sectors and real variables in the economy, the inflation rate of this aggregate price index must be given to the model exogenously. In other words, the model does not solve for the inflation rate but rather for relative prices and sectoral outputs given an exogenously specified time path of the aggregate price level. Domestic prices influence supply and demand decisions in all sectors. On the supply side, it is necessary to specify for each sector of production the technological conditions and the behavioral rules that influence supply decisions in response to changing prices. Technological constraints are given by a production function for each sector. The production functions chosen allow for substitution between types of labor and between labor and capital inputs. While fixed input-output coefficients are generally used, substitution between intermediate inputs and capital and labor
 - A-4 - is permitted under certain specifications (see Section B below). In addition, within intermediate inputs, substitution among types of energy in production in response to relative price changes is captured by adjusting the input- output coefficients of energy inputs (petroleum and coal). There are several additional points to note about the production function formulation being used. Sectoral capital stocks are fixed within periods, reflecting the assumption that capital cannot be moved across sectors once installed. Sectoral capital stocks are updated period to period by subtracting depreciation and adding net investment in the dynamic part of the CGF. model. In the model, sectoral capacity utilization is a function of the overall degree of import rationing in the economy and of the dependence of an individual sector on imported intermediate inputs (see Section B below). This formulation reflects the view that temporary shortages or delays in intermediate imported inputs can have an effect on domestic output levels. In sectors in which substitution possibilities between energy sources (coal and petroleum) or between aggregate intermediate inputs and aggregate value added are permitted, there are also assumed to be adjustment costs in the form of lowered capacity utilization that prevent the full cost-reduction benefits of the substitution from accruing immediately. Finally, in the production function, the labor input is an aggregation of labor of different types. The model identifies four such types: unskilled labor employed in the non- agricultural sectors, including workers with lower professional education, semi-skilled workers, and unskilled workers; skilled labor employed in the non-agricultural sectors, including the remaining skill and educational labor categories; agricultural labor (appearing only in agriculture); and labor employed in the urban service sectors (appearing only in the service sector). In both agricultural and the non-agricultural sectors, output supply
 - A-5 - is simply determined by available inputs and is given by the production function. In forward runs of the model, input supplies and hence output levels in these sectors are projected exogenously. In historical runs, they are set at their historical levels. In the non-agricultural sectors that comprise the core of the model, however, output supply depends not only on technology but also on the behavioral rules guiding the output and employment decisions of individual producers. The firm's decision to hire a new worker depends on a comparison between the market wage and the marginal value product of that worker. Aggregate demand for labor of each type is obtained by summing over the individual sectoral demands. On the supply side, the supplies of each labor type are fixed exogenously during each static period and updated dynamically. Wages adjust to clear the labor markets. In the dynamic part of the model, labor supplies can be adjusted to allow for the gradual migration of agricultural labor into the non-agricultural pool. A.2 Foreign Trade In the model, total foreign exchange available for imports depends not only on export earnings, but also on available foreign capital inflows. The CGE model distinguishes four different sources of capital flows: net remittance inflows; net factor service income; foreign borrowing net of amortization and interest payments; and changes in official foreign exchange holdings. In historical runs of the model, each of these capital flows is set at its actual annual dollar value for each year; in forward runs, the dollar values of these are set exogenously according to the projections undertaken as part of the CEM Mission review of external creditworthiness. As noted earlier, desired imports by sector depend on the relative prices of imports and imperfect domestic substitutes. With an equilibrium exchange rate, the market for foreign exchange must clear, so that total
 - A-6 - expenditures on imports must be equal to the sum of total exports, net foreign capital flows, and reserve changes. With a disequilibrium exchange rate, however, there is no guarantee that desired imports will not exceed export earnings and net foreign capital inflows, so the model must specify how to reduce import demand or otherwise bring the foreign exchange market into equilibrium. Currently, four alternative methods of achieving equilibrium in the foreign exchange market are possible. The first two are the most familiar: first, allow the exchange rate to respond flexibly to supply-demand imbalance, since raising the exchange rate will make imports more expensive, and exports cheaper, to external purchasers; second, one can leave the exchange rate fixed and allow net capital inflow to increase (or decrease) to achieve balance. The model also allows for two other possible policy regimes to restrict actual imports to the total of available foreign exchange. The first regime is a simple quantity rationing scheme. Sectors are allowed to obtain a certain exogenously specified fraction of their desired imports, reflecting both the existence of differential controls on imports of raw materials, capital goods, and consumer goods, and the preferential treatment of priority sectors in import rationing. This quantity rationing regime is a "fixprice" regime in the sense that the user-price of foreign exchange remains fixed at the official rate in spite of an overall shortage. The final alternative is to model a flexible-price (or "flexprice") rationing scheme, called rationing by premium. In contrast to fixprice rationing, in flexprice rationing those who demand foreign exchange for imports bid up the actual price of foreign exchange until at the new price the demand for foreign exchange equals the supply. Under this system, the demanders of foreign exchange have to pay a premium over the official exchange
 - A-7 - rate in order to obtain the foreign exchange they need. The complexities of these import rationing schemes and their impact on economic behavior are more fully discussed in Section B. A.3 Income and Product Demand To complete the static CGE model, it is necessary to develop the demand side of the model. This is accomplished by tracing through the incomes generated by the production of output in the economy and the various demands they induce. There are three kinds of recipients of income in the model: productive enterprises in the agricultural and non-agricultural sectors; households; and the government. The model contains an elaborate set of accounting and behavioral rules to determine how value-added or factor income generated in the course of production is distributed among these different income recipients. Basically, the distribution of value added in each sector depends on: (1) the size of the wage portion in total value added; (2) enterprise decisions about the distribution of their net income between savings and distributed profits; and (3) the various taxes that influence the distribution of value added between the private and government sectors. To obtain components of demand for output, the model specifies saving and expenditure behavior for the three types of income recipients identified. The income remaining with agricultural and non-agricultural enterprises after they have distributed wage incomes to their workers is assumed either to be distributed to owners of capital or retained by the enterprise and therefore made available for investment expenditure in fixed or working capital. The income flowing into the government sector from various taxes and other contributions from households and enterprises is used for two basic purposes: to finance government expenditures on the output of the productive sectors, and to finance investment. Finally, households are
 - A-8 - assumed to save a fraction of their disposable (after tax) income and to spend the rest on the output of the productive and non-productive sectors. Household income in the model is defined to include the inflow of foreign remittances. In the model, total investment activity in the economy can either be specified as determined by the available supply of savings, or a fixed investment/GDP proportion can be maintained by requiring savings rates of certain groups to adjust, or a mixture of the two in which the public investment/GDP ratio is fixed but private investment is endogenously determined according to fixed savings rates. The total amount of investment funds is distributed among different sectors by exogenously specified shares that can be adjusted from model run to model run and from period to period within a run. The sectoral shares of investment are an important policy variable in the model, capturing the effects of policy-induced allocations of capital among priority sectors and barriers to capital mobility across sectors. The implications of different investment strategies on economic performance can be analyzed and contrasted by comparing the model results under alternative assumptions about the sectoral distribution of investment funds. This is further discussed in the next section of this appendix. The investment allocation shares by sector specify the distribution of investment demand by sector of destination, that is by the sector in which additions to the capital stock actually occur. Investment by sector of origin in turn refers to the demand for the output of a particular sector that results from the investment activity or additions to capacity occurring in a sector of destination, and is obtained through the use of a capital coefficients matrix.
 - A-9 - In addition to investment demand for output, the model distinguishes intermediate demand and total consumption demand, encompassing both personal and government consumption. A.4 Market Clearing Conditions According to the CGE model formulation, for a given set of sectoral domestic prices and the exchange rate, it is possible to specify both sectoral supplies and sectoral demands. Market clearing requires that prices adjust until the resulting sectoral supplies and demands are equal. The task of the static, within-period CGE model is to find a set of wages and prices such that these labor and product market clearing conditions are satisfied and such that the total demand for foreign exchange is consistent with the available supply of foreign exchange. A solution represents an economy-wide equilibrium in labor and product markets and in the foreign exchange market, given exogenously specified market constraints and sectoral availabilities of labor and capital. The model solution does not represent a neoclassical free-market equilibrium. But it does represent a market equilibrium solution constrained by behavioral and institutional specifications believed to represent a realistic picture of the Turkish economy. A.5 The Dynamic CGE Model In general, the role of the dynamic phase of the CGE model is to update all the exogenous variable entering the static model. The most important exogenous variables that need updating include: world ($) prices of imports and exports; the nominal exchange rate; the domestic price index; the sectoral allocation of investment funds, and the resulting changes in sectoral capital stocks; the growth of the different categories of domestic labor; and the net foreign capital inflow figures. Some variables (remittance flows,
 - A-10 - household consumption behavior, the growth of domestic labor supplies) are updated using simple time trends, growth rates or exogenous projections. Others are updated to reflect assumptions about the likely effects of policy instruments. In forward runs of the model for the purposes of plan analysis, the projections of the Bank's RMSM model are used whenever possible to adjust exogenous foreign capital inflow variables. B. Modifications in the CGE Model The most important changes from the earlier TGT model can be classified into three areas, each of which is discussed in further detail below: (1) Foreign trade regime. One of the strengths of the CGE model is its ability to simulate the effect of various foreign trade regimes on trade, resource allocation and growth. With Turkey facing severe balance of payments crises throughout the late 1970's and into the early 1980's, modeling the foreign trade regime has required the specification of increasingly more sophisticated institutions and behavior on both the import side (mixed quantity and premium rationing) and export side (complex export subsidy and tax rebate schemes). (2) Investment allocation. In Turkey, the government plays a major role in the allocation of investment resources through its control over the Public Investment Program. It is therefore important to distinguish between the allocation of public investment, which is a policy instrument easily controlled by the government, and private investment, which is influenced by the full range of market profitability criteria and can be affected only indirectly by government policy choices. (3) Production technology. In a period notable for the frequency and magnitude of shocks to the relative price structure, the normal modeling
 - A-11 - specification of a fixed production technology becomes undesirably restrictive, especially where one is attempting to focus on projections over the medium term in which some input substitution could be expected to occur. B.1 The Foreign Trade Regime The most complex aspect of the foreign exchange regime in Turkey has been the combination of mechanisms used to ration imports during periods of foreign exchange shortage. The earlier version of the model permitted the specification of either quantity or premium rationing schemes to allocate available imports among competing users; however, the events of the 1978-81 crisis have illustrated that frequently both systems were used simultaneously. The adaptation of the model to capture the features of a "mixed" system of quantity and premium rationing permits a more realistic and flexible portrayal of the intricacies of the foreign exchange regime. The model's treatment of the import rationing scheme, and the efficiency losses that result from the misallocation of resources that occurs ("rent-seeking") are described below. The existence of substantial unsatisfied demand for foreign exchange at the official exchange rate requires that the available supply be rationed among users. In the model, two kinds of import rationing mechanisms are assumed to operate. First, under fixprice or quantity rationing, actual sectoral imports are restricted to some fraction of desired imports. These imports are allocated to demanding sectors directly, with the importer paying a price that reflects only the official exchange rate and tariff. The impact of this quantity rationing on each sector depends on the composition of its imports and the extent of the quantitative restrictions applied to each imported commodity. Import users are rationed in the sense that they receive fewer imports than they desire at the low (official) price; at the same time, however, the firm is receiving an implicit rent by obtaining a scarce resource
 - A-12 - at a lower price than it would be willing to pay for it. The second rationing mechanism is a flexprice or premium rationing scheme, in which enterprises that do not have access to sufficient foreign exchange to meet their needs pay a premium over the official exchange rate to obtain the necessary foreign exchange. This flexprice rationing scheme presupposes the existence of a functioning secondary market for foreign exchange through which firms holding foreign exchange can sell it for a premium above the existing official exchange rate. The system is equivalent to setting a uniform tariff on all imports just high enough to make the demand for foreign exchange equal the supply. The income flows generated by this mechanism accrue to the firms that are initially allocated the foreign exchange or are permitted to retain export earnings and therefore can sell foreign exchange at a premium above the official exchange rate. There is clearly a range of institutional arrangements that constitute a continuum of possibilities for which quantity and premium rationing represent polar cases. For example, a commonly observed arrangement in Turkey is that foreign exchange is allocated directly to an enterprise for its own use, but it is also allowed to import intermediate inputs for other domestic enterprises who supply it with intermediate inputs. Such a system falls somewhere between pure quantity and uniform premium rationing. To capture this diversity, the model permits the simultaneous operation of the two polar schemes, thus approximating a more realistic mix in practice. It is important to stress, however, that the relative importance of fixprice versus flexprice rationing over time must be specified exogenously, based upon information on the evolution of the foreign exchange regime over the particular period. Regardless of the mix of quantity and premium rationing used, the
 - A-13 - existence of unsatisfied demand for imports implies the existence of rents in the system. In the case of premium rationing, these rents are actual income flows, corresponding to the income received by holders of foreign exchange through its resale on the secondary market; for quantity rationing, no actual income flow accrues to import users, but an implicit rent is generated in that import users would be willing to pay more than the official price for the limited quantity of imports they can obtain. The presence of such rents gives rise to the possibility of inefficiency and waste as demanders of imports seek to acquire foreign exchange through non-market mechanisms. Such "rent- seeking" behavior has a real resource cost associated with it, as resources that might otherwise be used in production are redirected to such activities as lobbying for quantity allocations, negotiating complex agreements with groups of enterprises for the distribution of foreign exchange, and the like. Even if actual rent-seeking behavior does not develop to the full extent permitted by the existence of rents, it is of great interest to obtain measures of the total rental income being generated by the overall system of foreign exchange allocation. Such measures reflect the degree of strain on the allocation system arising from potential gains from rent-seeking. These strains include the possibility of illegal activities such as smuggling and bribery which are likely to emerge as the magnitudes of rents arising from efforts to ration foreign exchange get larger. On the export side, there has traditionally existed in Turkey substantial biases against exports, arising both from the persistent over- valuation of the exchange rate over long periods of time, as well as the high tariff barriers that have promoted import substitution at the expense of export possibilities. The 1980-81 policy reforms have made great progress in reducing the bias against export expansion, both by the major devaluation of
 - A-14 - the exchange rate that has been undertaken, as well as the adoption or expansion of a variety of schemes designed to provide increased incentives to current and potential exporters. As a result of the increased complexity of the export subsidy system, a number of different components of the overall subsidy have been explicitly modeled in the current version of the model. First, there continues to be a sectorally differentiated ad valorem export subsidy paid to exporters out of government revenue. Second, there also exists another fixed subsidy component that is funded not by the government but by non-exporters within a sector. This subsidy, which can be either positive or negative, captures the extent to which institutional mechanisms exist within a sector to support (positive rates) or impede (negative) producers from selling to foreign markets. Third, another component of the total subsity is derived endogenously from the exemption of exporters from the payment of tariffs on imported intermediate and investment goods used subsequently for the production of export products. The tariffs owed on these imports by each exporting sector are calculated explicitly within the model, and turned in to an ad valorem rate to allow their combination with other subsidy elements. Since the tariffs on these goods were never collected by the government, this subsidy component is modelled as a payment out of capital income to exporters rather than as a fiscal subsidy by the government. Fourth, another endogenous subsidy component representing the government's rebate to firms of production taxes on goods produced for export is explicitly calculated, and shows up as a government expenditure item since it is an actual rebate on taxes paid. Finally, the incentive effect of the export earnings retention scheme is captured by calculating a subsidy component equal to a certain percentage of the import premium rationing rate. For example, if the percentage is 10 percent of the premia rate, this
 - A-15 - corresponds to exporters being permitted to retain effective control over 10 percent of the foreign exchange they have earned, which can then be sold on the secondary market, used for imports, or transferred to other firms in need of foreign exchange. This scheme permits exporters to capture some of the rents associated with their earning foreign exchange, which partially redresses the bias against exports that emerges from reliance on import rationing schemes. Note that in the extreme case of one hundred percent retention, if there is a well functioning secondary market for foreign exchange, the system is essentially equivalent to a flexible exchange rate regime. However, since the scheme in Turkey permits less than full retention, and the secondary market is not perfect, the net effect of the retention scheme is to reduce, but not eliminate the bias against exports that emerges from the rationing of imports. B.2 Investment Allocation One modification made in the current version of the Turkey CGE model has been the programming of an explicit distinction between private and government investment allocation patterns. In earlier versions, the pool of total investment (fixed and inventory) had been allocated according to a single set of sectoral investment allocation shares. However, the desire to focus more carefully on the impact of differing private sector responses to the sizeable public sector investment program makes such an aggregate specification undesirable. The model now distinguishes between private and government investment, and it is now feasible to test the impact of alternative private investment scenarios, as well as to simulate the economywide effect of a variety of public investment programs over the medium term. Behaviorally, the investment allocation scheme remains quite
 - A-16 - simple. Rather than imposing a single sectoral allocation on both public and private investment, two separate allocations are permitted, with the aggregate allocation being determined endogenously as a linear combination of the two allocations, with the weights corresponding to the shares of public and private investment in total investment. The endogeneity of the overall sectoral allocation of investment, can be seen as depending on two distinct effects: (i) a shift in the relative importance of the public and private sectors in total investment; and (ii) changes in the sectoral allocation of investment by either the public or private sector. With regard to the first effect, shifts in the public vs. private balance in total investment can occur in a number of ways. First, in the simplest case when the model is savings-driven (total investment is set equal to available savings), both the government and private actors (firms and households) are saving according to exogenously specified savings rates. If government revenue should increase faster (slower) than the income base out of which private actors save, the government's share of total investment should increase (decrease) if the savings rates are held constant. Second, when the model is investment-driven, the government is still modeled as saving an exogenously fixed proportion of its total revenue. However, in order to guarantee that the desired investment level is reached, it is necessary to increase or decrease private savings to eliminate any savings deficit or surplus. Although one could conceivably make the savings rates of all private actors (or only one) adjust to guarantee savings- investment balance, for the current version of the model the institutional (firm) savings rates are required to bear the adjustment burden. Consequently, if the share of investment in GDP is exogenously specified as
 - A-17 - rising in this investment-driven version, then the share of private in total investment will also increase if the government savings rate remains constant, and there is no substantial change in the ratio of government revenue to GDP. Finally, with the mixed macro closure rule, the public investment/GDP ratio is fixed, so that the government savings rate must adjust; private actors are assumed to save according to exogenously fixed savings rates, so that the aggregate investment/GDP ration remains endogenous. With this scenario, the public share of total investment will increase if the public investment/GDP ratio rises, assuming no major changes in the relative incomes of private actors in the economy. The second effect represents a change in the sectoral mix of investment by either the public or private sector. In the case of the public sector, this corresponds to changes in the objectives of the public sector investment program, and is readily captured by placing trends in the sectoral public investment shares over time. In the private sector, the intersectoral pattern of investment over time can be specified exogenously as well, or the operation of market forces can be simulated by permitting private investment allocation to respond to changes in sectoral rental rates. While the modifications presented above permit a much more detailed examination of alternative investment allocation scenarios, it is important to note that the model still fails to treat several important features central to the savings-investment balance in developing countries. First, and most important, there is still no treatment of the financial sector in the model, so that the role of interest rates and asset markets in eliciting savings and facilitating investment are completely omitted. Second, the model still contains a relatively crude portrayal of the public sector deficit. For investment allocation, what is important is the public and private shares in
 - A-18 - total investment; however, in the model, these are assumed to be the public and private shares in total savings as well. The private and public sectors are each modeled as investing all that they save; if the government in reality borrows from the private sector to finance its own investment program, either via bond markets or inflationary monetary policy, this must be captured within the model by including this flow of resources in government revenue from taxation of the private sector. B.3 Production Technology Most multisector CGE models have relied on a Leontief fixed input coefficients specification with regard to input requirements. Over a planning period as long as a decade, where significant relative price changes may occur or where the government may implement policies designed to induce changes in the input mix, this specification is inadequate for capturing the dynamic responses of the economy. To begin to allow for the possibility of some price-sensitive, endogenous input response to changing market conditions, the current version of the CGE model includes two separate substitution processes. The first process addresses the massive increase in the relative price of petroleum in the last decade, which should over time lead to substantial substitution of other fuels, especially lignite, for imported crude and refined petroleum. In light of the Turkish government's stated intention to invest heavily in the domestic production of coal and to encourage petroleum conservation, and the dominant share of petroleum and petroleum products in total imports, it becomes critically important to simulate this substitution possibility within the model. This has been done by defining a sectoral aggregate "energy" input coefficient, which is a CES aggregation of the base year coal and petroleum input coefficients in each sector. In subsequent periods, as the relative
 - A-19 - prices of the two energy inputs diverge, substitution between the two alternative energy inputs is permitted according to sectoral substitution elasticities, subject to the constraint that the aggregate energy input coefficient remain constant. The use of sectorally differentiated elasticities is an acknowledgement that certain production technologies (e.g. electricity generation) present greater substitution possibilities than others. The second substitution process addresses the fact that with fixed physical input coefficients in production, there can be no substitution between intermediate material inputs and primary factors of production (labor and capital). As a result, if aggregate intermediate input prices should rise relative to labor and capital, the share of intermediate costs in total costs will rise as well. While this simplification may be adequate for the short run, in the medium to long term some substitution between material inputs and value added is to be expected. To capture this phenomenon, the modeling of the production activities in the model has been generalized to incorporate some degree of substitution between physical inputs on the one hand and capital and labor on the other. If one leaves the input coefficients unchanged, as in the earlier version of the model, the share of intermediate costs in total costs is determined endogenously as a result of changes in the prices of these inputs. An alternative specification is now included in which the value share of intermediate costs is held constant; in other words, if intermediate input prices rise ten percent relative to other prices, the physical input coefficients will be lowered by ten percent so that the share of intermediate in total costs remains unchanged. This specification assumes a Cobb-Douglas production function in aggregate intermediate inputs and primary factors.

The process can be viewed as consisting of two separate stages: first, obtaining the best, most-up-to-date data and information on the base year, plus information on actual trends for dynamic applications; and second, using the data to estimate the parameters of the model. The first stage requires insuring accounting consistency among data obtained from a variety of sources and the second stage involves "calibration" of the model so that, given the data that is being supplied, the model captures the important characteristics of the period under study. In working with the base year data, the process of generating consistent data and estimating structural parameters was greatly expedited through the use of the social accounting matrix (SAM) generator program that has been developed at the World Bank. Through the use of this program, the tedious process of adjusting and readjusting different variables to achieve accounting consistency is simplified and automated. At the same time, using base data as a point estimate, the program also generates values of all of the structural parameters needed by the CGE model so that the data that emerge from the process represent an equilibrium solution in the first year. Calibration of the dynamic model involves a more informal procedure of adjusting various structural parameters over time so that the model "tracks" the economic trends of the period. doc.repnme: Turkey : recent economic performance and medium-term prospects, 1978-1990
doc.abstracts: By 1978, Turkey was in the midst of the most serious foreign exchange and economic crisis it had experienced in three decades. This paper presents an analysis of the 1978-80 crisis period in Turkey and an exploration of the feasibility and sustainability of the ongoing export-led recovery. A computable general equilibrium model of the Turkish economy attempts to capture the basic features of the 1978-81 foreign exchange disequilibrium in Turkey and evaluate their role in the crisis through a series of historical simulations. The model is then used to undertake a series of forward runs for the 1982-90 period which reflect alternative scenarios as to the success and viability of the ongoing shift in Turkish development policy from inward-looking import substitution to outward-focused export expansion. An overview of the model is included in the body of the paper, while Appendix I contains a detailed description and algebraic summary. Appendix II outlines the data sources used for the study.
